pros: Friendly staff and challenging work
cons: I have no cons at this time

review_title: Challenging but good pay and you can bring change - FYI name change to UNC Health Southeastern
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Lumberton, NC
pros: Extremely nice staff. Salt of the earth people. Great teamwork. Small unit, max capacity 15-16 beds. The unit actually feels like it embraces change, which is unusual in nursing. It needs a lot of help, but the CEO actually rounds and asks for how things can be done differently. Base Staff make their normal hourly, a $2/hr critical care pay, and shift diff. Then covid stipend on top of pay if they work their scheduled 6 shifts in two weeks. Internal agency gets flat rate of 75/hr - no PTO, insurance/benefits ect. This pay is EXTREMELY good for this area.
cons: Challenging population. Only 3 attendings that rotate through the month. One on the unit at a time. Attendings often very late (arriving 10-11am) on a regular basis, or leave during the day for hours on end. Teaching hospital, often run by inexperienced residents. Often under staffed nursing and CNAs, having 3 patients is not abnormal. Sometimes 3 vented. Safety is an issue. Not a policy driven unit. Often controversy on how things are supposed to be done.

pros: Salaries are fair and coworkers are friendly
cons: At times my work feels unappreciated.

pros: really trying to provide to the underserved in our area
cons: staff is underpaid by local standereds

pros: free membership at fitness facility
cons: overwork, underpay. will not respect your personal or school schedule and will schedule you for shifts you cannot work. will reject PTO

review_title: Always finding some way to take money out of our pockets.
pros: Most of the people I work with are great and work very hard. Always helpful and willing to lend a helping hand.
cons: Management is always finding out ways to take money out of our pockets. Covid is on the rise again but they cut out our Covid incentive raise. Which was very much to start with unless you were a doctor, nurse, or management. You are always overworked, understaffed, and underpaid. No matter what you do, you never qualify for a raise. The cafeteria food is awful and the prices are outrageous. You can eat at Outback cheaper than in the cafeteria. The more work you do, the more they want you to do, but they never want to pay you any more or give you any incentives. Insurance costs are very high with very few rewards. Management and the whole system needs a lot of changes. Need changes to help the average worker.

review_title: Was not very helpful to new graduate nurses
job_title: Registered Nurse in East Lumberton, NC
pros: Decent benefits, always able to pick up extra shifts, some really nice and helpful seasoned nurses
cons: There were many cliques, longer term employees were not very helpful or nice to new nurses. Seasoned day shift nurses would talk about night shift new graduates behind their backs and laugh at them instead of helping them. It was sink or swim.

review_title: former employee of that left for TX for 6 months due to sickness in my wifes' family.  Came back, a few months ago  apap
job_title: Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist in Lumberton, NC
pros: good staff to work with.until just before I retired.  Tried to come back and work  (Former CRNA who had 24 years of experience .  Applied to work in PACU but was frustrated that with all my experience of 24 years I could not get a position.
cons: A lot of friends at SRMC who are not happy with how things are going for staff.

review_title: Management is the root of all problems @ SRMC.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Lumberton, NC
pros: Salary is comparable to other facilities in the region.
cons: Management continues to perform under the "Good ole boy" system.  Most of the management staff are hired because of who they know or their status in the community.  There is a total disconnect between management and staff.  Favoritism on the part of management is evident throughout.  The management staff spend all their time in meetings and there is never any communication as to what is actually discussed.  Staff are not included in problem solving or decision making.  There is no participation by staff on committees.  Of all hospitals I have worked, SRMC management is by far the worse.   We have been told a take over is foreseeable in the future.   We can only hope and pray there will be positive change and the current management staff will be evaluated on their true merits, not by who they are or their ability to spin a conversation to their benefit.

pros: Close for those not wanting to travel to work.
cons:
Advancement is reserved for those who know somebody, who knows somebody....
Most people leave for advancement because the facility talks about supporting staff, but when it comes time to push staff, those with less expertise and experience get higher positions because of who they know.
Even the doctors prefer to leave, some before their contracts are completed.

pros: I loved my job at SRMC. The nurses I worked with were all amazing and the Doctors were wonderful as well. I worked third shift while attending school full time. I was offered overtime several times from other floors that were short handed. They would call me to see if I wanted to work when I was off.
cons: I got sick a lot even when I went overboard on washing my hands and wearing masks around people that I didn't even need to wear a mask around.

pros: Small facility, friendly staff, doctors easy to reach. The facility received bonus on christmas. Nurses worked together with doctors to get the job done
cons: The hospital was a friendly environment. The only drawback was that in any given day a nurse could end up with seven patients and at times patients weren't distributed by aquity

review_title: I’ve learned so much from this hospital and everyday I learn something new.
pros: The staff is very friendly and helpful and the patients/family members are sweet. My manager works with my schedule really well and I have been able to further my education because of this.
cons: We just received a new computer system and that was a challenge to get familiar with. Occasionally, we are under staffed and it makes for a long 12 hour shift.

pros: It is a small hospital with a small mentality.  It is isolated and its only connection to the world is that I-95 runs by it.  It has the potential to be a great hospital but its leader are determined to be followers and not leaders.  in the 6+ years I spent there, I was hoping that the culture would change due to a new CEO.  It was the opposite, the CEO followed the small town mentality.  The only pro was that I was employed and closer to home.
cons:
Please, run the other way.  Some of the reasons are as follows:
Lack of true leadership
Individuals in leadership lack the expertise
Individuals in leadership are the friend of a friend, a fellow church goer, or a relative.
40%+ of the community chooses to find healthcare services even if they travel 30 or more miles away from campus.
The nurses do not stay there very long therefore there exist a large group of traveling nurses.
An atmosphere of "today a hero, tomorrow a zero" is very dominant due to the lack of a sense of direction.
An environment of uncertainty
Not open to suggestions
Quickly label a negative or not a team player when offering advise
Managers do not have the capabilities to think on their own and perfunctionally  follow instructions.
Management quickly work to silent the voices of those seeking to help achieve the organization goals.

review_title: Horrible Benefits and low pay...Look elsewhere for a job!
job_title: Oncology Certified Pharmacy Technician in Lumberton, NC
pros: The pharmacy department is a great department to work in as the director really supports the employees.
cons: Horrible benefits...during the new employee orientation, they make the benefits sound spectacular BUT once they have you locked in to a job, you realize those benefits are not what they proclaimed they were. I needed a specialist but Southeastern did not even have one in that specialty in the Southeastern network (only providers directly affiliated and employed with SRMC). So I still have not addressed that health issue because I can not afford to pay out of network costs. My daughter who is in college and lives 2.5 hours from home needed to be seen but could not come home because I can not afford for her to have a car. She was seen by a medical clinic near her college and diagnosed with the flu....that visit cost me $317.... our insurance requires that you meet a $1500 deductible if you are not seeing a SRMC provider that is in the network.  I spoke with HR and they basically told me sorry but oh well. They froze our sick time and stopped letting us accrue any sick time and now we only accrue PTO but they have not given us any of our sick accrual back.  If we want to use that frozen sick time, we are required to be seen by a SRMC provider and we are required to submit a sick note from that provider. The pay is lower than the average pay and they will not compensate you with hazard pay when you work in their Oncology Pharmacy.

pros: Co-workers are 99% of the time competent in their field which produces quality teamwork.
cons: Unqualified management which leads to layoffs and bad financial decisions. You wouldn't hire someone with a degree in basket weaving to be a nurse, would you?
